Available online 20 July 2025 Article Hydrogen production via ammonia decomposition on molybdenum carbide catalysts: Exploring the Mo/C ratio and phase transition dynamics Bowen Sun a 1 Siyun Mu a 1 Bingbing Chen a * Guojun Hu a Rui Gao b * Chuan Shi a * a State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals School of Chemistry Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China b College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot 010021, Inner Mongolia, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Inner Mongolia University Hohhot Inner Mongolia 010021 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot 010021, Inner Mongolia, China * Corresponding author 1 Contributed equally to this work. The deployment of non-precious metal catalysts for the production of CO x -free hydrogen via the ammonia decomposition reaction (ADR) presents a promising yet great challenge. In the present study, two crystal structures of α-MoC and β-Mo2C catalysts with different Mo/C ratios were synthesized, and their ammonia decomposition performance as well as structural evolution in ADR was investigated. The β-Mo2C catalyst, characterized by a higher Mo/C ratio, demonstrated a remarkable turnover frequency of 1.3 s–1, which is over tenfold higher than that of α-MoC (0.1 s–1). An increase in the Mo/C ratio of molybdenum carbide revealed a direct correlation between the surface Mo/C ratio and the hydrogen yield. The transient response surface reaction indicated that the combination of N* and N* derived from NH3 dissociation represents the rate-determining step in the ADR, and β-Mo2C exhibited exceptional proficiency in facilitating this pivotal step. Concurrently, the accumulation of N* species on the carbide surface could induce the phase transition of molybdenum carbide to nitride, which follows a topological transformation. It is discovered that such phase evolution was affected by the Mo-C surface and reaction temperature simultaneously. When the kinetics of combination of N* was accelerated by rising temperatures and its accumulation on the carbide surface was mitigated, β-Mo2C maintained its carbide phase, preventing nitridation during the ADR at 810 °C. Our results contribute to an in-depth understanding of the molybdenum carbides’ catalytic properties in ADR and highlight the nature of the carbide-nitride phase transition in the reaction. Graphical Abstract Schematic decomposition of ammonia on the α-MoC and β-Mo2C, incorporating N fate and phase transitions of two molybdenum carbides under thermal activation. Keywords Molybdenum carbides Phase transition Nitridation Recombination Ammonia decomposition reaction 1 Introduction The secondary energy source, hydrogen, is recognized as a clean alternative energy carrier that plays a crucial bridging role in the development of renewable and fossil energy sources [ 1–3 ]. However, numerous hydrogen-dependent technologies are restricted by issues like the challenge of cost-effective storage and low transport efficiency [ 4–6 ]. Alternatively, hydrogen can be chemically stored in molecules such as methane, methanol, ammonia, metal amine salts, and metal hydrides [ 7–10 ]. Among these compounds, NH3, which serves as a hydrogen storage carrier, exhibits a relatively higher storage density (17.8 wt%) and energy density (3000 Wh/kg) [ 11 ]. Moreover, with its mature manufacturing and transportation technology, it facilitates distributed hydrogen production for on-site supply, avoiding issues arising from hydrogen storage and transportation [ 12–14 ]. The ADR yields high-purity hydrogen without any CO x (CO2, CO) emissions to supply proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and avoid electrode poisoning [ 15–17 ]. ADR is a thermodynamically endothermic reaction Eq. (1), the equilibrium conversion of NH3 is approximately 99.1% at 400 °C and atmospheric pressure [ 18 ]. However, without a catalyst, ammonia cannot be completely decomposed even at super high temperatures [ 19,20 ]. Thus, rational manipulation of catalyst composition and structure is pivotal for realizing efficient ADR. (1) N H 3 ↔ 3 2 H 2 + 1 2 N 2 , Δ H 298 K θ = + 46.22 k j ⋅ m o l - 1 Recently, various catalysts have been developed for ADR, including noble and non-noble metal catalysts [ 21–23 ]. The high cost of Ru limits its large-scale commercial applications in NH3 decomposition, and thereby low-cost non-precious metal (Fe, Co, Ni, Mo, etc.) catalysts have attracted more attention [ 24–31 ]. Among them, molybdenum carbides and nitrides, exhibiting catalytic behaviors similar to noble metals, have been considered as inexpensive alternatives to noble metal catalysts. The presence of high-energy sites (e.g., twin boundaries, stacking faults, steps, and defects) in Mo carbides and nitrides ensures relatively high reaction rates in ADR [ 32 ]. Jia et al. [ 33 ] have synthesized Mo2N nanobelts through temperature-programmed nitridation of MoO3 precursors under the optimal synthesis conditions of MoO3. It was discovered that the Mo2N catalyst exhibits excellent NH3 adsorption and N2 dissociation adsorption capabilities, and its morphology and structure are well-preserved after the reaction. For disperse molybdenum nitride, Zhang et al. [ 34 ] synthesized molybdenum nitride (η-MoN and γ-Mo2N) nanocrystals within 2D mesoporous silica/graphene hybrid sheets. The well-dispersed Mo nitride nanocrystals, enhanced by rGO as an electron donor, form favorable Mo-N bonds, resulting in high catalytic activity for MoN/SBA-15/rGO and Mo2N/SBA-15/rGO for ADR. Albeit lots of research focuses on Mo nitride, only several reports have been published on application of Mo carbide in ADR. In the early years, Choi [ 35 ] reported that Mo carbide was active for ammonia decomposition and the catalytic activities of some Mo carbon catalysts were comparable or even better than those of Pt/Al2O3, showing potential as a substitute for noble metal catalysts. More recently, Zhang et al. [ 32 ] reported that Mo2C showed good ammonia decomposition performance, but it tends to convert into molybdenum nitride at high reaction temperatures (600 °C). Actually, the unique properties of molybdenum carbide lie in their multiphase structure, and different crystal phase of α-MoC (Cubic), β-Mo2C (Hexagonal), η-MoC (Hexagonal), γ-MoC (Hexagonal) affect the catalytic behaviors obviously [ 36–38 ]. In the context of reactions involving ammonia, the dynamics structural changes of molybdenum carbide are crucial to the reaction mechanism and reaction efficiency [ 39 ]. Therefore, it is necessary to study the structural evolution process of molybdenum carbide in ammonia. Herein, two-phase molybdenum carbide (α-MoC and β-Mo2C) catalysts were prepared using temperature-programmed nitridation and carbonization method. The important role of the surface Mo/C atomic ratio of molybdenum carbide in ammonia decomposition was firstly clarified, and the higher surface Mo/C atomic ratio, the higher reaction rate in ammonia decomposition was obtained. Moreover, both α-MoC and β-Mo2C catalysts were involved in a topology phase transformation during the ADR at 600 °C, where α-MoC changed into Mo2N (FCC), and β-Mo2C transformed into MoN (HCP). A stable conversion was achieved during the tested 120 h, notwithstanding the quick deactivation over β-Mo2C during the first 15 running hours. Furthermore, the temperature effects on the phase transformation of Mo x C in ADR were clarified and it was found that above the temperature at which the rate of N* and N* combination was fast enough for N2 production, β-Mo2C could maintain its carbide phase without nitridation in ADR at 810 °C. These findings not only deepen the understanding of molybdenum carbides’ catalytic properties related to Mo/C ratio, but also emphasize the intrinsic nature of phase transformation between carbide and nitride in ADR. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of MoO3 precursor The MoO3 precursors were prepared by calcining ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd) in a muffle furnace at 500 °C (with a heating rate of 10 °C/min) and maintaining this temperature for 4 h. Subsequently, the calcined product was crushed and sieved to 40–60 mesh for later use. 2.1.2 Preparation of α-MoC α-MoC was synthesized with reference to our previous work [ 40 ]. Specifically, the obtained MoO3 was loaded into the vertical quartz reactor. High-purity ammonia (150 mL/min) was introduced as a nitrogen source from room temperature (RT) to 700 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min for 2 h. After cooling, the 20% CH4/H2 mixture (with a flow rate of 150 mL/min) was introduced and the sample was carbonized for 2 h using the same temperature-rise procedure. Finally, the sample was cooled down to RT and then passivated with 1% O2/Ar (15 mL/min) gas for 12 h to obtain the stable α-MoC. 2.1.3 Preparation of β-Mo2C For the preparation of β-Mo2C, the MoO3 powder was placed in the reactor with a 20% CH4/H2 (150 mL/min) atmosphere. The temperature was raised from RT to 300 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min and then from 300 to 700 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min. The sample was held at 700 °C for 2 h. After naturally cooling to RT, the passivation process was carried out in a 1% O2/Ar mixture gas for 12 h to obtain the stable β-Mo2C. 2.2 Characterizations The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was achieved on a Rigaku D/max X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 0.15404 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The diffraction peaks were recorded in the 2θ range of 10°–90° with a scanning rate of 10°/min. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were collected on an SU6600 instrument (Hitachi, Japan). Samples for SEM imaging are deposited on conductive paste. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on the JEOL JEM-2100 operating at 200 kV. The samples were suspended in ethanol and sonicated for 30 min to allow for adequate dispersion. Then, the suspension was deposited onto ultra-thin carbon film-coated copper grids. CO chemisorption was measured at –78 °C (keep this temperature with liquid nitrogen) on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption. Before testing, the catalysts were activated in 20% CH4/H2 at 590 °C for 60 min. The catalysts were pretreated at 200 °C under vacuum for 4 h to remove the excessive adsorbate. Subsequently, nitrogen sorption measurements were conducted on a physical adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2460) to obtain the surface area and pore size distribution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were obtained on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250 Xi system with Al Kα radiation serving as the excitation source. Raman spectra were acquired using a DXR Microscope (Thermo Fisher, the United States) with an excitation laser wavelength of 514.5 nm. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH₃-TPD) analysis of the catalyst was carried out to investigate the adsorption behavior of ammonia using an infrared absorption spectrometer (SICK-MAIHAK-S710, Germany). The catalysts were pretreated at 500 °C in a pure H2 flow (40 mL/min) for 1 h and then purged under Ar flow at 600 °C for 30 min. After cooling to 25 °C, the catalysts were exposed to pure NH3 for 30 min at atmospheric pressure, followed by purging under Ar for 1 h to remove the residual NH3. The NH3-TPD was conducted by starting to heat to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min with a supply of Ar while the electrical signal of the desorbed NH3 was recorded. Temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD) was conducted on a fixed-bed reaction reactor equipped with a Pfeiffer Vacuum OmniStar GSD320 online mass spectrometer. In a typical H2-TPD experiment, prior to the measurement, 0.2 g of the catalyst was activated in a stream of H2 (40 mL/min) for 2 h at 500 °C and then cooled down to room temperature (RT), followed by purging with Ar for 1 h. The H2-TPD experiment was performed by heating the catalyst at a rate of 10 °C/min from RT to 600 °C under Ar flow (40 mL/min). A mass spectrometer recorded the H2 (m/z = 2) desorption profiles. NH3 pulse of catalysts was investigated to clarify the desorption of H2 and N2 during ammonia decomposition. Catalyst pre-activation was performed as that in H2-TPD. NH3 pulse (in Ar, 40 mL/min) was injected at different temperature. Gas desorption (H2 (m/z = 2), N2 (m/z = 28), NH3 (m/z = 17)) was recorded by Pfeiffer Vacuum OmniStar GSD320 online MS. The N2-TPD test was performed after pulsing NH3 at 400 °C and after a smooth baseline purge with Ar, the temperature was programmed to ramp up from 400 °C to detect N2 (m/z = 28) signal. 2.3 Ammonia decomposition activity test The ADR was evaluated on a fixed-bed reactor of 6 mm inside diameter and 8 mm outside diameter. Typically, 50 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh) and quartz sand mixture was positioned between two layers of quartz fibers in the center of a quartz tube, which was then placed vertically in an electronic furnace. The temperature of the outer wall of the quartz tube at the location of the catalyst bed was measured by a type K thermocouple. The catalysts were tested in pure NH3 at a weight hly space velocity (WHSV) of 30000 mL/(g·h). Prior to the test, the molybdenum carbide catalysts were pretreated in 20% CH4/H2 (40 mL/min) at 590 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 400 °C. Temperature-dependent conversion tests were carried out from 400 to 600 °C in 50 °C steps under atmospheric pressure. At each step, the temperature was stabilized for 30 min to allow the reaction to reach equilibrium. The stability tests were conducted with a WHSV of 60000 mL/(g·h) at 600 °C. Outlet gas (N2 and NH3) concentrations were analyzed by an on-line GC Chromatography (GC7890II, Tianmei) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a Porapark Q column. The NH3 conversions (X NH3) was calculated by Eq. (2), and H2 formation rates (r H2) was calculated by Eq. (3). (2) X N H 3 = F N H 3 i n l e t - F N H 3 o u r l e t F N H 3 i n l e t × 100 % where F NH3 inlet and F NH3 outlet represent molar flow rate of inlet and out gas, respectively. (3) r H 2 = 1.5 × F N H 3 i n l e t 22.4 × X N H 3 m c a t 2.4 DFT calculation details All calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab Initio simulation package (VASP) [ 41,42 ]. The electron-ion interaction was described with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [ 43,44 ]. The electron exchange and correlation energies were treated within the generalized gradient approximation in the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof formalism (GGA-PBE) [ 45 ]. The energy cutoff of plane wave basis was set to 450 eV, electron smearing width of σ = 0.2 eV was employed according to the Methfessel-Paxton technique, and the MP k-point sampling was utilized. All transition states were estimated using the Climbing Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) method [ 46 ], and stretching frequency analysis was performed to verify whether a transition state associated with a solely imaginary frequency. The barrier (E a) and reaction energy (∆E r) were calculated according to E a = E TS – E IS and ∆E r = E FS – E IS, where E IS, E FS and E TS are the total energy of the corresponding initial state (IS), final state (FS) and transition state (TS), respectively. In the calculations, the α-MoC is the cubic cell (fcc), and its lattice constant is 4.332 Å (experimental = 4.270 Å). For β-Mo2C, the lattice constant is α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, a = 6.061 Å, b = 6.050 Å and c = 4.710 Å. For surface models of α-MoC (111) and β-Mo2C (101), both of the unit cell p (3′3) and the 3′3′1 k-point sampling were used. Totally, α-MoC (111) surface has 48 Mo and 48 C atoms, in which 16 Mo and 32 C were fixed; the β-Mo2C (101) has 40 Mo and 24 C atoms, in which 16 Mo and 8 C were fixed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations Molybdenum carbides were synthesized using a temperature-programmed carbonation process applied to MoO3, which was derived from the calcination of ammonium paramolybdate (Figs. 1(a) and S1). Typically, α-MoC is produced through a two-step thermal treatment process that includes nitridation in pure ammonia, followed by carbonation with a 20% CH4/H2 mixture. The β-Mo2C was prepared via a single-step carbonization process using a 20% CH4/H2 mixture. Freshly prepared molybdenum carbide catalysts require a mild passivation treatment in 1% O2/Ar to preclude combustion upon exposure to air. Fig. 1(b) shows that the XRD pattern of α-MoC corresponds to cubic crystalline (JCPDS card No. 65-0280), whereas that of β-Mo2C is a hexagonal crystalline phase (JCPDS card No. 35-0787). No other species were identified in the XRD pattern. Raman spectra (Fig. S2) manifested the formation of MoO3 covering layers on the surfaces of α-MoC and β-Mo2C, which was in accordance with previous studies [ 47,48 ]. The integration of XRD and Raman results implies that the crystal structure of molybdenum carbide remains intact during the passivation process, with only surface oxidation. SEM images reveal that α-MoC exhibits a lamellar structure with a thickness of 300–400 nm, whereas β-Mo2C displays an irregular polyhedron morphology (Fig. S3). The HRTEM images demonstrate that the lattice spacings of 0.25 and 0.23 nm correspond to the (111) and (101) crystal planes of cubic α-MoC and hexagonal β-Mo2C, respectively (Figs. 1(e), (f) and Fig. S4). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions indicated the existence of nanopores within α-MoC and an almost negligible presence of nanopores in β-Mo2C (Fig. S5). The BET surface areas of α-MoC and β-Mo2C were measured to be 126 and 13 m2/g, respectively. Moreover, as shown in Table S1, the quantity of CO adsorbed by α-MoC (529 μmolCO/gcat) was sevenfold greater than that of β-Mo2C (72 μmolCO/gcat). This indicates that the carbonation process leads to dissimilarity in the crystal structure of molybdenum carbides and affects the specific surface area and thereby their exposed active site numbers. The electronic state and valence bands of molybdenum carbides were investigated using XPS. Fig. S6 illustrates the survey XPS spectrum of α-MoC and β-Mo2C, with the detection of Mo 3d, C 1s and O 1s, respectively. The presence of surface oxygen was further confirmed. The C 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 1(c)) of both Mo carbides exhibit the existence of carbide species (Mo–C) at 283.7 eV, along with other MoC x O y species such as C–O (286.3 eV), C=O (288.8 eV) [ 49,50 ], respectively. Based on the Mo 3d spectrum, the elemental state distribution on the surface of molybdenum carbides was estimated through deconvolution. The Mo 3d spectrum of both α-MoC and β-Mo2C could be deconvoluted into four peaks, indicating the existence of four distinct species on the surface of molybdenum carbides. The main Mo 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 binding energies (228.6 and 231.7 eV) are assigned to Mo2+ state for β-Mo2C. Remarkably, Mo2+ is involved in the Mo–C bonding in molybdenum carbides [ 50 ]. Meanwhile, the latter two pairs of doublets at 229.3, 232.4 and 230.2, 233.3 eV might be related to Mo4+ and Mo δ+ (Mo-C-O) species, respectively. Besides, the doublet with Mo 3d energies of 232.8 (3d 5/2) and 235.8 (3d 3/2) eV is identified, revealing that Mo6+ are formed. It can be posited that Mo4+, Mo δ+ and Mo6+ are molybdenum oxide species generated during the passivation process [ 48 ]. Based on the fitting result of Mo 3d spectrum, the ratios of Mo4+, Mo δ+, and Mo6+ species in β-Mo2C could be determined as about 11%, 15%, and 23%, respectively, and the corresponding proportions in α-MoC are 14%, 16%, 25%. In addition, the variations in binding energies (BEs) of α-MoC and β-Mo2C also verify the interaction between Mo and C species, which gives rise to distinct local electronic states of Mo. Specifically, the Mo–C binding energy in Mo 3d of β-Mo2C (228.6 eV) is slightly negative than that of α-MoC (228.8 eV), suggesting that electron transfer from the C atom to the adjacent Mo atoms in β-Mo2C, which is in agreement with literature reports [ 37,51–54 ]. The surface Mo/C ratio is calculated in accordance with the XPS core level peak areas, which have been corrected using the atomic sensitivity factor (Table S2). The resulting Mo/C ratios for β-Mo2C and α-MoC were 1.48 and 0.73, respectively (Fig. 1(d)). This suggests that α-MoC presents a carbon-rich surface due to the presence of a significant amount of Mo–C bonds, whereas β-Mo2C is a Mo-rich surface, in accordance with previous reports [ 55 ]. In addition, the electron paramagnetic resonance spectrum in Fig. S7 exhibits a centrosymmetric signal line centered at ∼2.002, demonstrating that both α-MoC and β-Mo2C produce defects sites (e.g. C vacancies), with the latter being more abundant [ 56,57 ]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The performance of the α-MoC and β-Mo2C catalysts for the ammonia decomposition reaction was evaluated at various temperatures in pure NH3 with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 30000 mL/(g·h). As shown in Figs. 2(a) and S8, the NH3 conversion increases rapidly with rising reaction temperature, which is in line with the endothermic nature of the ADR. It is evident that the ammonia conversion rates of α-MoC and β-Mo2C approach the equilibrium conversion rate at 600 °C. However, at lower temperatures ranging from 400 to 550 °C, the NH3 conversion over β-Mo2C is higher than that of α-MoC. Specifically, at 550 °C, the conversion of β-Mo2C reaches 92%, while that of α-MoC is only 68%. It is noteworthy by normalizing the hydrogen production rate at 450 °C close to the kinetic region with the specific surface area of the catalyst, it reveals that the specific reaction rates of β-Mo2C is much higher than that of α-MoC, i.e., 0.43 vs. 0.03 (mmolH2/(m2·min)), as illustrated in Fig. 2(b). Furthermore, the turnover frequency calibrated by CO chemisorption (TOFs) for β-Mo2C was 1.30 s–1, representing more than 10 times higher than that of α-MoC (0.10 s–1) (Fig. 2(c)), which shows a great disparity of phase dependence in ADR. Kinetic studies were conducted to investigate the phase-dependent catalytic behavior of molybdenum carbides. The β-Mo2C catalyst showed a lower value of 89.8 kJ/mol for the apparent activation energy (calculated according to the Arrhenius equation) compared to α-MoC (107.4 kJ/mol), consistent with its superior intrinsic activity in ammonia decomposition (Fig. S9(a)). Furthermore, the H2 reaction order for α-MoC (–0.53) was more negative than that of β-Mo2C (–0.35), suggesting stronger hydrogen inhibition on α-MoC during the reaction (Fig. S9(c)). It is apparent that β-Mo2C with higher Mo/C ratio exhibits much superior activity for NH3 decomposition, which is an unconventional performance as behaved in most Mo carbide based catalyzed reactions, such as water-gas-shift reaction [ 40,51,58 ], reverse water-gas shift reaction [ 39,59 ], and steam reforming [ 60–62 ], in which α-MoC is generally more active than β-Mo2C. This discovery inspired us to explore the effect of Mo/C ratio on the catalytic performance of ammonia decomposition. Specifically, treatment of α-MoC in a H2/Ar atmosphere at 650 °C (Fig. S10) with prolonged time could remove carbon from surface to lattice accordingly, accompanied by the phase and Mo/C ratio changes [ 63 ]. As shown in Fig. 2(d), we observed that new weak diffraction peaks appeared upon 30 min reduction (noted as α-MoC-30 min for example), which matched well with those of β-Mo2C. This suggests that the α-MoC catalyst undergoes reconfiguration and the lattice carbon was reduced by H2 into CH4, which was further confirmed by the H2-TPR (Fig. S11). With the prolonged reduction time, the diffractions of β-Mo2C gradually increases. Such phase transition induces α-MoC lattice contraction (Fig. S12(a)) [ 64 ], regulating the surface Mo/C ratio as well as the electronic state of Mo. However, overly extended pretreatment leads to an excessive extraction of carbon from α-MoC, and metallic Mo phases were detected over α-MoC-240 min (Fig. S12b). Combined with the quasi-in situ XPS results, the Mo/C ratio of the H2/Ar-treated α-MoC catalyst increased from 1.42 to 1.77 (Fig. S13 and Table S2). Subsequent ammonia decomposition tests revealed that the treated catalyst exhibited enhanced ammonia decomposition reactivity (Fig. 2(e)). The order of NH3 conversion over the catalysts at 550 °C is as follows: α-MoC-30 min < α-MoC-60 min < α-MoC-90 min < α-MoC-120 min. Whereas metal Mo leads to a decrease in ammonia decomposition activity, as is the case with α-MoC-240 min in Fig. S14. Furthermore, we found a linear relationship between the surface Mo/C ratio and ADR activity (Fig. 2(f)). A higher Mo/C atomic ratio endows the catalyst with a high H2 production rate. This demonstrates that molybdenum carbide-based catalysts with a suitably increased Mo concentration are beneficial for improving ammonia decomposition activity. However, the surface of α-MoC-240 min is dominated by metallic Mo, causing the Mo/C ratio to deviate from the linear range and making it unsuitable for correlating with ammonia decomposition performance. To further explore the stability of molybdenum carbide, a long-term stability test was conducted at 600 °C at a WHSV of 60,000 mL·g-1·h-1. The high temperature and high space velocity were sufficient to probe the thermal durability of the catalyst. For α-MoC, following a marginal decrease within the first few h, the NH3 conversion was stabilized at 65% throughout the 120 h test, and no perceptible deactivation was detected. In contrast, β-Mo2C exhibits an initial ammonia conversion rate of 85%. However, it rapidly deactivates by 22.3% within the first 10 h of the test. It then stabilizes with a constant ammonia conversion of 66% in the tested 120 h. While α-MoC and β-Mo2C catalysts demonstrate comparable apparent activity following a 120-h stability test, their operational mechanisms and structural evolution diverges significantly. These distinctions will be further substantiated through post-reaction characterizations. What's more, a similar phenomenon of the Mo carbide catalysts could be obtained from the cycling test results in Fig. S15, in which the α-MoC retained approximately 94% of the initial activity after five uninterrupted cycling tests, whereas the NH3 conversion of β-Mo2C decreased by 27%. In addition, during the 12-h stability test, all catalysts with varying Mo/C ratios showed a slight decrease in activity initially, followed by stabilization (Fig. S16). 3.3 The adsorption and desorption property of Mo carbides Since molybdenum carbide with different Mo/C ratio show such distinct catalytic behaviors in NH3 decomposition reaction, the surface reactions such as NH3-TPD, H2-TPD and the designed two-step surface reactions were carried out to illustrate the mechanism behind ADR activity. The NH3-TPD results of α-MoC and β-Mo2C samples, which were quantified by an infrared absorption spectrometer. According to the NH3 temperature-programmed test, both molybdenum carbide is almost catalytically inert below 400 °C, exhibiting negligible NH3 decomposition activity (to H2 and N2) within this temperature regime. Consequently, our experimental design prioritized the precise quantification of NH3 adsorption capacity on the catalyst surface, and N2/H2 signals were not monitored simultaneously. As shown in Fig. 3(a) , α-MoC and β-Mo2C showed similar NH3 desorption curve profiles, with overlapped ammonia desorption peaks at ca. 114 and 205 °C. These peaks are indicative of ammonia desorption occurring at the acidic sites present on the catalyst surfaces. Based on the peak area of ammonia desorption, α-MoC (495 μmol/g) desorbs more ammonia than β-Mo2C (375 μmol/g), suggesting that the total amount of ammonia adsorbed on α-MoC is higher than that on β-Mo2C. However, considering the significant difference in specific surface areas between them, when the ammonia adsorption amount is normalized to the specific surface area of the catalyst (Fig. S17), the amount of ammonia adsorbed per unit specific surface area of β-Mo2C is 7 times that of α-MoC. Moreover, the ammonia adsorption amount is normalized by CO chemisorption for β-Mo2C was 5.2, representing more than 5 times higher than that of α-MoC (0.9). The chemisorption behaviors of hydrogen over the carbide catalysts were investigated by exploring the H2-TPD. As shown in Fig. 3(b), β-Mo2C was found to have a broad desorption peak near 120 °C, which is due to the weak adsorption of hydrogen. Additionally, a weaker hydrogen desorption peak at 350 °C was detected, indicating the presence of stronger sites for H2 adsorption. However, besides the desorption peak at 130 °C, obvious high-temperature desorption peaks appeared on α-MoC at 315 and 480 °C respectively. The results indicate that, besides the higher amount of H2 desorption over α-MoC, it possesses much stronger H2 adsorption sites as compared with β-Mo2C. It is worth noting that the majority of H2 desorbed below 400 °C, and above this temperature, the NH3 decomposition reaction began to take place, suggesting that the desorption of H2 produced from ADR should not inhibit the reaction. A two-step surface reaction was designed to evaluate the recombination and desorption rate of adsorbed N2 on the two Mo carbides, where ammonia was introduced at 400 °C first, followed by temperature programmed desorption in Ar. As depicted in Fig. 3(c), hydrogen signals (m/z = 2) were immediately detected on both molybdenum carbides after ammonia injection, indicating that the occurrence of the ammonia dissociation and the immediate H2 desorption. Notably, the intensity of H2 over α-MoC was much weaker than β-Mo2C, being consistent with the higher NH3 decomposition activity of β-Mo2C. While there is no signal for nitrogen evolution. This implies that the recombination and desorption of nitrogen atoms is limited at this temperature. During the subsequent TPD process shown in Fig. 3(d), nitrogen was detected as it was desorbed during the elevated temperatures. The N2 desorption peaks on the β-Mo2C surface at ca. 505 °C, which was lower than that of α-MoC (540 °C). This rationally designed two-step surface reaction gives clear evidence that N* and N* recombination should be the rate limiting step of NH3 decomposition reaction [ 29,65–68 ]. β-Mo2C seems to facilitate the nitrogen recombination and desorption, thereby leading to superior ammonia decomposition activity. This will be further discussed in the DFT calculation section. 3.4 Structural evolutions Considering the possible structural transformations of molybdenum carbide in ammonia, the spent catalysts is characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. 4(a) , after 4 h of reaction in pure NH3 (600 °C, WHSV = 60000 mL/(g·h)), the (111) and (200) crystal plane of α-MoC was shifted towards a high angle. This phenomenon is attributable to the difference in the atomic radius of C (77 pm) and N (75 pm), the insertion of N into the α-MoC lattice can induces surface lattice disorder [ 64 ]. The amount of doped N determined by element analyzers (Table 1 ), indicates that a considerable amount of N has already been incorporated into the α-MoC lattice after 4 h of reaction. Not surprisingly, the α-MoC phase transform into cubic Mo2N (JCPDS card No. 25-1366) after 120 h reaction. This is also confirmed by high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images, as shown in Fig. 4(d), Mo2N (111) (0.25 nm) of lattice fringe spacing could be observed on surface of spent α-MoC catalyst. Meanwhile, the EDS element mapping images further shown that Mo and N was homogeneously dispersed. According to Fig. 4(a), the XRD pattern of β-Mo2C after 4 h reaction was a mixture of hexagonal β-Mo2C and hexagonal MoN (JCPDS card No. 25-1367), while the carbide was totally carburized into nitride and only MoN was preserved after 120 h reaction. This was further confirmed by HR-TEM and EDS element mapping. The lattice fringe spacing of MoN (111) (0.24 nm) could be detected (Fig. 4(e)), suggesting that β-Mo2C is converted to the MoN phase during the ADR at 600 °C. Therefore, the rapid deactivation of β-Mo2C in long-term stability as well as cyclic stability is attributed to its phase transition to MoN (Fig. S18), which is the true stable phase during the stability tests. To understand the structural evolution process of molybdenum carbide during the reaction, we carried out temperature-programmed surface reaction (NH3-TPSR) tests to monitor the gas products generated during the NH3 decomposition. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the consumption of NH3 (m/z = 17) is accompanied by the generation of H2 (m/z = 2) and N2 (m/z = 28). It was detected that the temperature of H2 production from β-Mo2C is 385 °C, lower than that of 400 °C for α-MoC, in accordance with the superior activity of β-Mo2C vs. α-MoC. The rate of ammonia consumption and the production of N2 and H2 accelerated with increasing temperature, indicating the enhanced catalytic activity with increasing temperatures. The complete conversion of NH3 over β-Mo2C is observed at around 585 °C, which is 600 °C for α-MoC. Notably, a slight decrease in H2 and N2 production was observed after the temperature exceeded 600 °C, possibly due to structure transformation as detected in Fig. S19. Simultaneously during the NH3-TPSR process, the CH4 signal was detected, which should originate from the carbide which was reduced by H2 from ammonia decomposition. The amount of CH4 generated first increases and then decreases as the temperature rises, and the maximum generation temperature is ca. 615 °C. α-MoC produces more CH4 than β-Mo2C, which is consistent with its abundant Mo-C motifs as revealed by XPS (Fig. 1(c)). In particular, CH4 is generated at ca. 460 °C, later than the temperature at which ammonia decomposition occurs, indicating that scissoring of N–H bond of NH3 takes place before N (from NH3) and C (from MoC x ) exchange, in accordance with previous reports that Mo sites should be the active sites for NH3 dissociation, with H* and N* formation [ 69–71 ]. As revealed in Fig. 3(a), 2H* easily combined and immediately released immediately even at low temperatures (400 °C), while N* and N* combination is the rate limiting step in ADR, and being affected by the reaction temperature and carbide surface. It is obvious that rising the temperature and the β-Mo2C surface facilitate the N* and N* combination and release. Upon the N* accumulation on the carbide surface, it might diffuse into the carbide lattice and induce the N (from NH3) and C (from MoC x ) exchange, driven by the increasing surface N* chemical potential. Thereby, the phase transformation from carbide to nitride should be determined by the N*and N* combination, and if the generated N*and N* could immediately combine to N2, there should be no accumulation of N* on the carbide surface and thereby suppress the nitridation of carbide. So the temperature effects on the carbides phase transformation over α-MoC and β-Mo2C were investigated, and shown in Fig. S20. Upon the ADR reaction at 450, 615 and 810 °C for 400 min over α-MoC and β-Mo2C, respectively, the corresponding XRD results were collected. Treatment of molybdenum carbide in NH3 at 450 °C produced H2 and N2 and a faint CH4 signal was immediately detected (Figs. S20(a1), (b1)). At this temperature, the produced H2 can only remove trace surface carbon from molybdenum carbide, with the lattice carbon being retained. Since the rate of N* production and its migration into the bulk are kinetically slow at 450 °C, the crystal phases of both α-MoC and β-Mo2C were maintained (Fig. 4(d)) after 400 min’ reaction. Notably, elemental analysis tests showed that N was enriched on the surface of both molybdenum carbides, suggesting that N was doped in the surface layer of molybdenum carbide (Table S3). Meanwhile, the insertion of N resulted in a slight decrease in the ammonia conversion rate (Fig. S21). When molybdenum carbide was exposed to NH3 at 615 °C (Figs. S20(a2), (b2)) at same reaction time, XRD showed that β-Mo2C was partially converted to MoN, and α-MoC was basically converted into Mo2N. This implies that a substantial fraction of the dissociated N atoms migrated into the bulk of molybdenum carbide and that the nitridation rate of α-MoC was more rapid due to its difficulty in N* and N* combination. If the temperature is raised to 810 °C, no NH3 signal is detected by mass spectrometry during NH3-TPSR (within 400 min), indicating complete decomposition of NH3 (Figs. S20(a3), (b3)). It is noticeable that β-Mo2C keeps its crystalline phase well during the NH3 decomposition reaction (Fig. 4(b)), indicating that N–N combination rate greatly accelerates at this temperature, and showing the evidence towards desorption from the carbide surface without participation in the nitridation process. Elemental analyses further provide only trace amounts of N-doped (Table S3). However, α-MoC transforms into β-Mo2C and metallic Mo, with trace N elements detected by elemental analyses (Table S3), indicating that α-MoC cannot be stabilized in a hydrogen-rich atmosphere at high temperatures. Temperatures higher than 810 °C might be necessary to avoid the accumulation of N* and nitridation of Mo carbides, while this seems to be unreliable, since metastable α-MoC could not preserve its structure under extremely high temperatures like 810 °C. Based on the foregoing, it is found that β-Mo2C can preserve its carbide phase in ammonia decomposition reaction at high temperatures, when the rate of N–N complexation is sufficiently rapid, and atomic N tends to be removed directly without participating in inward penetration [ 72 ]. Based on the experimental results, a schematic diagram of the phase transition of ammonia decomposition under different phases of molybdenum carbide is presented in Fig. S22. 3.5 DFT calculations To better understand the catalytic performance in the experiments, the mechanisms of ADR on the models of α-MoC (111) and β-Mo2C (101) were investigated by the DFT calculations (all the possible reaction routes are given in Fig. S23). As the most favorite pathways show in Fig. 5(a) , the three N–H bonds of ammonia molecule on α-MoC (111) were dissociated in sequence forming the surface N and H atoms with the barriers of 1.50, 0.86 and 1.32 eV, respectively, and then the two surface N atoms combination into N2 molecule need overcome a much higher barrier of 2.33 eV, which is the rate-determining step (RDS). On β-Mo2C (101), the first two N–H bonds of ammonia molecule could be dissociated into the surface NH species and H atoms with the barriers of 1.53 and 1.65 eV, respectively; then the NH species will combine with a surface N atom forming into the surface NNH with a barrier of 1.68 eV, which is the highest barrier in the whole reaction of ADR; after that, the NNH can be dissociated easily into N2 molecule with a lower barrier of 0.89 eV. For comparison, the latter RDS is much lower than the former (1.68 vs. 2.33 eV), suggesting the β-Mo2C has the superior catalytic performance of ADR, which is coincident with the experimental results. Furthermore, the other possible NHx coupling reactions also can be excluded on the α-MoC (111) and β-Mo2C (101) models because of the very high reaction barrier (Figs. 5(b) and (c)). 3.6 Discussion Given that the face-centered cubic structure of α-MoC presents a larger specific surface area, endowing it with more active sites and remarkable capabilities in numerous hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions such as the water-gas shift reaction, reverse water-gas shift reaction, and methanol reforming reaction, yet its application in ammonia decomposition remains scarcely explored. In contrast to these catalytic systems, the present study reveals that β-Mo2C exhibits inherently superior ammonia decomposition activity compared to α-MoC. Moreover, β-Mo2C maintains its carbide phase, resisting nitridation during ADR at elevated temperatures. These results have motivated our current work to conduct ammonia decomposition on α-MoC and β-Mo2C, aiming to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimize their catalytic efficiency. Our findings suggest that the Mo/C ratio in molybdenum carbides significantly influences their catalytic efficacy in the ADR. β-Mo2C, characterized by a higher Mo/C ratio, exhibits a tenfold increase in turnover frequency (TOF) compared to α-MoC. Subjecting α-MoC to a pretreatment in a H2/Ar atmosphere at 650 °C results in an elevated Mo/C ratio, which, in turn, correlates linearly with the H2 yield from ADR. Kinetic analysis of the transient surface reaction reveals that the conjunction of N* and N* species, derived from NH3 dissociation, constitutes the rate-determining step in ADR, with β-Mo2C demonstrating enhanced performance in facilitating this critical step. Notably, the production of CH4 during NH3-TPSR (as depicted in Fig. 4(c)) indicates that the accumulation of N* on the catalyst surface may participate in a C (from the carbide) and N* (from NH3) exchange, leading to a phase transition to molybdenum nitride. This hypothesis is supported by XRD analysis following long-term stability testing (Fig. 4(a)). The temperature at which CH4 production occurs (approximately 460 °C) is higher than the temperature range for ammonia decomposition (around 400 °C), suggesting that it is not the C–N exchange that triggers the ammonia decomposition reaction. Additionally, the impact of temperature on the phase transitions of α-MoC and β-Mo2C during ADR was elucidated. It was observed that after 400 min of reaction at 450 °C, both α-MoC and β-Mo2C preserved their crystalline structures. However, elemental analysis (Table S3) revealed an enrichment of nitrogen on the surface of the molybdenum carbides. Reacting up to 615 °C led to the nitridation of both Mo carbides, indicating that surface N* species migrated into the bulk, causing bulk nitridation. Increasing the temperature further enhanced the kinetics of N2 desorption, with β-Mo2C retaining its crystalline phase throughout the ammonia decomposition process. In contrast, the metastable α-MoC failed to preserve its phase stability in either NH3 or H2/N2 environments and transitioned into Mo and β-Mo2C. This suggests that despite the recombination and desorption of N* and N* species on the α-MoC surface at elevated temperatures, such as 810 °C, the lattice carbon is continuously reduced by hydrogen and escapes from the bulk phase, leading to the inability to sustain its crystalline structure (as depicted in Fig. 4(b) and Fig. S24). 4 Conclusions We prepared molybdenum carbide catalysts (α-MoC and β-Mo2C) for the effective production of hydrogen through the decomposition of ammonia. The β-Mo2C catalyst, characterized by a higher surface Mo/C atomic ratio, exhibited superior performance in the ammonia decomposition process. Specifically, the hydrogen generation rate in the kinetic regime for β-Mo2C was measured at 5.6 mmol/(gcat·min), which significantly exceeded the rate of 3.21 mmol/(gcat·min) observed for α-MoC. Moreover, β-Mo2C demonstrated a TOF that was an order of magnitude higher than that of α-MoC at 450 °C. Mechanistic insights indicate that the conjunction of N* and N* species from NH3 dissociation represents the rate-limiting step in the ammonia decomposition reaction, with β-Mo2C showing a distinct advantage in enhancing this critical step. Significantly, the deposition of N* species on the carbide surface has the potential to induce a topological phase transition from molybdenum carbide to nitrides. This phase transition is modulated by both the Mo-C surface composition and the reaction temperature. With an increase in temperature, the binding kinetics of N* species are accelerated, leading to a reduction in their accumulation on the carbide surface. Consequently, β-Mo2C can retain its carbide phase during ammonia decomposition at 810 °C, whereas the metastable α-MoC undergoes transformation into metallic Mo and β-Mo2C in the presence of NH3 or H2/N2. S.M., B.C., and G.H. discussed the results and B.S., R.G., and C.S. cowrote the manuscript. All authors read and commented on the manuscript. coredata.dc:description: The deployment of non-precious metal catalysts for the production of CO x -free hydrogen via the ammonia decomposition reaction (ADR) presents a promising yet great challenge. In the present study, two crystal structures of α-MoC and β-Mo2C catalysts with different Mo/C ratios were synthesized, and their ammonia decomposition performance as well as structural evolution in ADR was investigated. The β-Mo2C catalyst, characterized by a higher Mo/C ratio, demonstrated a remarkable turnover frequency of 1.3 s–1, which is over tenfold higher than that of α-MoC (0.1 s–1). An increase in the Mo/C ratio of molybdenum carbide revealed a direct correlation between the surface Mo/C ratio and the hydrogen yield. The transient response surface reaction indicated that the combination of N* and N* derived from NH3 dissociation represents the rate-determining step in the ADR, and β-Mo2C exhibited exceptional proficiency in facilitating this pivotal step. Concurrently, the accumulation of N* species on the carbide surface could induce the phase transition of molybdenum carbide to nitride, which follows a topological transformation. It is discovered that such phase evolution was affected by the Mo-C surface and reaction temperature simultaneously. When the kinetics of combination of N* was accelerated by rising temperatures and its accumulation on the carbide surface was mitigated, β-Mo2C maintained its carbide phase, preventing nitridation during the ADR at 810 °C. Our results contribute to an in-depth understanding of the molybdenum carbides’ catalytic properties in ADR and highlight the nature of the carbide-nitride phase transition in the reaction.
